comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Streetview Unveiled in 1906, per the DIA City Hall itself was officially opened by Lord Leiutenant (Earl of Aberdeen) 1 Aug 1906 (per its DIA ref).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Thank you, Niall. And the day and the hour?  ;)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The memorial was unveiled by the Marquess of Londonderry on 9 June 1906 says Belfast City Council Heritage Directory

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Fantastic! But there's still the little matter of the time of day?  :D
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
The base of the Dufferin statue is made up of a turbaned Indian astride a cannon and holding a sabre, as well as a snowshoed Canadian with a musket, sitting on a dead moose.

Seriously!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Sounds very tasteful! Presumably trying to cram a career over many geographic locations into one memorial?

Presumably the Marquess of Londonderry must be one of the behatted gentlemen (as unveiler - if that's a word)?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Naughty moose!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Did someone call? It's odd. The sun appears to be from more or less due west at about 60 degrees above the horizon. Did city hall used to face the other way? The latest it could be from the height is about three o'clock but the sun looks too far west for that.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The occasion hit the headlines in Australia - "Newsy Notes from Ireland ... " - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/20828551

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The sculptor was Frederick William Pomeroy - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F._W._Pomeroy

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Shadows suggest noon. .ish

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Deffo never faced the other way. This was taken from Donegall Square West...

And where have you been hiding yourself? Was almost thinking it was safe to post a photo of Larne...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Lovely Newsy Note, but quietly shaking fist at them that no mention of time is given!  :)

Would imagine that the poetically inclined might find the moose, never mind anything else, quite inspiring?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Ah. I assumed it was north. In that case, it's about 12 noon. There's no mystery. There's also no mystery about my disappearance - I was on holiday in France.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
There is a report in the Irish Times,  Page 7   Friday 8 June 1906

So maybe the 9th of June is in doubt?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Will check immediately, if not sooner!

Checked and you're right - it was Friday, 8 June 1906...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think we broke the Belfast City Council heritage Directory page :(

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Honestly, I can't take you lot anywhere! Still no time of day in any of the newspapers, but the Irish Independent of Thursday, 7 June 1906 said:
The Marquis of Londonderry, who has been in attendance on the Prince of Wales, is expected to reach London to-day from Madrid, leaving later on for Mount Stewart. He will reach Belfast in time to unveil the Dufferin Memorial.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: June 8, 1866 The Canadian Parliament meets for the first time in Ottawa. Was unveiling timed to honour 40th anniversity?

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] The sun looks to be coming from due south in the earlier photo, suggesting 12 noon. It has moved a bit further to the west in this one. I would hazard a guess that the unveiling was at 1pm but that the spectators had gathered some time before that.

comment.author: 60329026@N07
comment._content: I suggest that this image was recorded at lunch time judging by the number of workers standing on the ledges outside many of the windows and the large numbers of people at the windows, such activity would not have be tolerated during working hours.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/60329026@N07] Not even on such a special occasion?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 60329026@N07
comment._content: It would appear that my previous comment was incorrect as there are ladies in their Sunday best (complete with hats) at many of the windows and I have highlighted some children sitting on the window ledges on the second floor, accordingly it is probable that some of the prople at the windows are family members of those working in the building
